Author: henning
Content: Those purple paragraph markers never stop being ridiculous.

Author: sethjohn
Content:
What is true 'de jure' may not be true 'de facto'.

With technologies available to suck your information back out of Facebook (the new versions of which will presumably evade detection), and plenty of people happy to use them, the legalities of information ownership will be irrelevant.

Author: run4yourlives
Content: I think the point is that it violates the spirit, if not the letter, of the whole "social network" idea.

Author: jakewolf
Content:
He knew what he was doing all along.

"That's part of my job to see how good their terms of service are, and how well enforced they are." http://scobleizer.com/2008/01/03/ive-been-kicked-off-of-face...

Since when is breaking a contract part of one's job?

Author: sethjohn
Content:
Again, the future of the web is being written by petty acts of criminality. (aka civil disobedience, aka breaking stupid rules)

Just as the entertainment industry will eventually have to adapt to the reality of file-sharing, regardless of the fact that the law is on their side...the future of data portability will be driven by technology development and people's willingness to break the rules, not by the Facebook TOS.

Author: tomjen
Content: If the data is on facebook servers, it is on private property and they have every right to decide who has access to their private property.

Author: tomjen
Content: Facebook is private property, so they can ban anyone they want (otherwise what is the point of the fourth amendment?)

Author: cstejerean
Content: what matters is that Facebook would disable your account for attempting to get your data out of it. For this and many other reasons I've deleted my Facebook account (and it wasn't easy).

Author: drm237
Title: Startup Reinvents Business Presentations And, Once Again, Itself

Author: ivankirigin
Content: "world wide web" arouses pretty specific imagery, I suppose
